{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Ovarian cyst | image = Benign Ovarian Cyst.jpg | caption = A simple ovarian cyst of most likely follicular origin | field = [[Gynecology]] | symptoms = None, bloating, lower abdominal pain, lower back pain<ref name=Women2014/> | complications = [[ruptured ovarian cyst|Rupture]], [[ovarian torsion|twisting of the ovary]]<ref name=Women2014/> | onset = | duration = | types = [[follicular cyst of ovary|Follicular cyst]], [[corpus luteum cyst]], [[Endometrioma|cysts due to endometriosis]], [[dermoid cyst]], [[cystadenoma]], [[ovarian cancer]]<ref name=Women2014/> | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = [[Ultrasound]]<ref name=Women2014/> | differential = | prevention = [[Hormonal birth control]]<ref name=Women2014/> | treatment = [[Conservative management]], pain medication, surgery<ref name=Women2014/> | medication = | prognosis = Usually good<ref name=Women2014/> | frequency = 8% symptomatic before [[menopause]]<ref name=Women2014/> | deaths = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> An '''ovarian cyst''' is a fluid-filled sac within the [[ovary]].<ref name=Women2014/> Often they cause no symptoms.<ref name=Women2014/> Occasionally they may produce bloating, lower abdominal pain, or lower back pain.<ref name=Women2014/> The majority of cysts are harmless.<ref name=Women2014/> If the cyst either [[ruptured ovarian cyst|breaks open]] or causes [[ovarian torsion|twisting of the ovary]], it may cause severe pain.<ref name=Women2014/> This may result in vomiting or [[Lightheadedness|feeling faint]].<ref name=Women2014>{{cite web|url=http://www.womenshealth.gov/publications/our-publications/fact-sheet/ovarian-cysts.html?from=AtoZ#|title=Ovarian cysts|date=November 19, 2014|website=Office on Women's Health|accessdate=27 June 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629070544/http://www.womenshealth.gov/publications/our-publications/fact-sheet/ovarian-cysts.html?from=AtoZ|archivedate=29 June 2015|df=}}</ref>
<!-- Cause and diagnosis --> Most ovarian cysts are related to [[ovulation]], being either [[follicular cyst of ovary|follicular cyst]]s or [[corpus luteum cyst]]s.<ref name=Women2014/> Other types include [[Endometrioma|cysts due to endometriosis]], [[dermoid cyst]]s, and [[cystadenoma]]s.<ref name=Women2014/> Many small cysts occur in both ovaries in [[polycystic ovarian syndrome]].<ref name=Women2014/> [[Pelvic inflammatory disease]] may also result in cysts.<ref name=Women2014/> Rarely, cysts may be a form of [[ovarian cancer]].<ref name=Women2014/> Diagnosis is undertaken by [[pelvic examination]] with an [[ultrasound]] or other testing used to gather further details.<ref name=Women2014/>
<!-- Treatment --> Often, cysts are simply observed over time.<ref name=Women2014/> If they cause pain, medications such as [[paracetamol]] (acetaminophen) or [[ibuprofen]] may be used.<ref name=Women2014/> [[Hormonal birth control]] may be used to prevent further cysts in those who are frequently affected.<ref name=Women2014/> However, evidence does not support birth control as a treatment of current cysts.<ref name=Grime2014>{{cite journal|last1=Grimes|first1=DA|last2=Jones|first2=LB|last3=Lopez|first3=LM|last4=Schulz|first4=KF|title=Oral contraceptives for functional ovarian cysts.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=29 April 2014|volume=4|issue=4|pages=CD006134|pmid=24782304|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD006134.pub5}}</ref> If they do not go away after several months, get larger, look unusual, or cause pain, they may be removed by surgery.<ref name=Women2014/>
<!-- Epidemiology --> Most women of reproductive age develop small cysts each month.<ref name=Women2014/> Large cysts that cause problems occur in about 8% of women before [[menopause]].<ref name=Women2014/> Ovarian cysts are present in about 16% of women after menopause and if present are more likely to be cancer.<ref name=Women2014/><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Mimoun|first1=C|last2=Fritel|first2=X|last3=Fauconnier|first3=A|last4=Deffieux|first4=X|last5=Dumont|first5=A|last6=Huchon|first6=C|title=[Epidemiology of presumed benign ovarian tumors].|journal=Journal de Gynecologie, Obstetrique et Biologie de la Reproduction|date=December 2013|volume=42|issue=8|pages=722–9|pmid=24210235|doi=10.1016/j.jgyn.2013.09.027}}</ref> {{TOC limit|3}}
==Signs and symptoms== Some or all of the following symptoms may be present, though it is possible not to experience any symptoms:<ref name=HELM2013 /> * [[Abdomen|Abdominal]] pain. Dull aching pain within the abdomen or pelvis, especially during intercourse. * [[Uterus|Uterine]] bleeding. Pain during or shortly after beginning or end of menstrual period; irregular periods, or abnormal uterine bleeding or spotting. * Fullness, heaviness, pressure, swelling, or [[bloating]] in the abdomen. * When a cyst ruptures from the [[ovary]], there may be sudden and sharp pain in the lower abdomen on one side. * Change in frequency or ease of [[urination]] (such as inability to fully empty the [[Urinary bladder|bladder]]), or difficulty with [[bowel movement]]s due to pressure on adjacent [[pelvic]] anatomy. * [[Constitutional symptom]]s such as [[Fatigue (physical)|fatigue]], [[headache]]s * Nausea or vomiting * Weight gain Other symptoms may depend on the cause of the cysts:<ref name=HELM2013 /> * Symptoms that may occur if the cause of the cysts is [[polycystic ovarian syndrome]] (PCOS) may include increased [[facial hair]] or [[body hair]], [[acne]], obesity and [[infertility]]. * If the cause is [[endometriosis]], then periods may be heavy, and intercourse painful.
The effect of cysts not related to PCOS on fertility is unclear.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Legendre|first1=G|last2=Catala|first2=L|last3=Morinière|first3=C|last4=Lacoeuille|first4=C|last5=Boussion|first5=F|last6=Sentilhes|first6=L|last7=Descamps|first7=P|title=Relationship between ovarian cysts and infertility: what surgery and when?|journal=Fertility and Sterility|date=March 2014|volume=101|issue=3|pages=608–14|pmid=24559614|doi=10.1016/j.fertnstert.2014.01.021}}</ref>
===Cyst rupture=== A ruptured ovarian cyst is usually self-limiting, and only requires keeping an eye on the situation and [[analgesic|pain medication]]s. The main symptom is abdominal pain, which may last a few days to several weeks, but they can also be asymptomatic.<ref>[http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/253620-overview#showall Ovarian Cyst Rupture] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928090329/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/253620-overview |date=2013-09-28 }} at [[Medscape]]. Authors: Nathan Webb and David Chelmow. Updated: Nov 30, 2012</ref> Rupture of large ovarian cysts can cause [[hemoperitoneum|bleeding inside the abdominal cavity]] and in some cases shock.
===Ovarian torsion=== Ovarian cysts increase the risk for [[ovarian torsion]]; cysts which are larger than 4 cm are associated with approximately 17% risk. The torsion can cause obstruction of blood flow and lead to [[infarction]].<ref name=eMedHealth>{{cite web |url=http://www.emedicinehealth.com/ovarian_cysts/article_em.htm |title=Ovarian Cysts Causes, Symptoms, Diagnosis, and Treatment |work=eMedicineHealth.com |accessdate= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307143243/http://www.emedicinehealth.com/ovarian_cysts/article_em.htm |archivedate=2007-03-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Diagnosis== [[File:2cmleftovariancyst.png|thumb|A 2 cm left ovarian cyst as seen on ultrasound]] Ovarian cysts are usually diagnosed by [[ultrasound]], [[CT scan]], or [[magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]], and correlated with clinical presentation and endocrinologic tests as appropriate. [[File:Trichromatic Color MRI of ovarian cysts.jpg|thumb|Four kinds of ovarian cysts on MRI]] ===Ultrasound=== Follow-up imaging in women of reproductive age for incidentally discovered simple cysts on ultrasound is not needed until 5 cm, as these are usually normal ovarian follicles. Simple cysts 5 to 7 cm in [[menopause#Diagnosis|premenopausal]] females should be followed yearly. Simple cysts larger than 7 cm require further imaging with [[magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] or surgical assessment. Because they are large, they cannot be reliably assessed by ultrasound alone because it may be difficult to see the soft tissue nodularity or thickened septation at their posterior wall due to limited penetrance of the ultrasound beam. For the [[corpus luteum]], a dominant ovulating follicle that typically appears as a cyst with circumferentially thickened walls and [[crenulation|crenulated]] inner margins, follow up is not needed if the cyst is less than 3 cm in diameter. In [[menopause#Diagnosis|postmenopausal]] patients, any simple cyst greater than 1 cm but less than 7 cm needs yearly follow-up, while those greater than 7 cm need MRI or surgical evaluation, similar to reproductive age females.<ref name="levine1">{{cite journal|last1=Levine|first1=D|last2=Brown|first2=DL|last3=Andreotti|first3=RF|last4=Benacerraf|first4=B|last5=Benson|first5=CB|last6=Brewster|first6=WR|last7=Coleman|first7=B|last8=Depriest|first8=P|last9=Doubilet|first9=PM|last10=Goldstein|first10=SR|last11=Hamper|first11=UM|last12=Hecht|first12=JL|last13=Horrow|first13=M|last14=Hur|first14=HC|last15=Marnach|first15=M|last16=Patel|first16=MD|last17=Platt|first17=LD|last18=Puscheck|first18=E|last19=Smith-Bindman|first19=R|title=Management of asymptomatic ovarian and other adnexal cysts imaged at US: Society of Radiologists in Ultrasound Consensus Conference Statement.|journal=Radiology|date=September 2010|volume=256|issue=3|pages=943–54|pmid=20505067|doi=10.1148/radiol.10100213}}</ref>
[[Image:Ovarian Cyst.JPG|thumb|right|An Axial CT demonstrating a large hemorrhagic ovarian cyst. The cyst is delineated by the yellow bars with blood seen anteriorly.]]For incidentally discovered [[Dermoid cyst|dermoids]], diagnosed on ultrasound by their [[pathognomonic]] [[Echogenicity|echogenic]] fat, either surgical removal or yearly follow up is indicated, regardless of patient age. For [[peritoneal inclusion cysts]], which have a crumpled tissue-paper appearance and tend to follow the contour of adjacent organs, follow up is based on clinical history. [[Hydrosalpinx]], or [[fallopian tube]] dilation, can be mistaken for an ovarian cyst due to its anechoic appearance. Follow-up for this is also based on clinical presentation.<ref name="levine1"/>
For multiloculate cysts with thin septation less than 3 mm, surgical evaluation is recommended. The presence of multiloculation suggests a [[neoplasm]], although the thin septation implies that the neoplasm is benign. For any thickened septation, nodularity, or vascular flow on [[color doppler]] assessment, surgical removal should be considered due to concern for malignancy.<ref name="levine1"/>
===Scoring systems=== There are several systems to assess risk of an ovarian cyst of being an [[ovarian cancer]], including the RMI (risk of malignancy index), LR2 and SR (simple rules). [[Sensitivity and specificity|Sensitivities and specificities]] of these systems are given in tables below:<ref name="KaijserSayasneh2013">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kaijser J, Sayasneh A, Van Hoorde K, Ghaem-Maghami S, Bourne T, Timmerman D, Van Calster B | title = Presurgical diagnosis of adnexal tumours using mathematical models and scoring systems: a systematic review and meta-analysis | journal = Human Reproduction Update | volume = 20 | issue = 3 | pages = 449–462 | year = 2013 | pmid = 24327552 | doi = 10.1093/humupd/dmt059 | issn = 1355-4786 }}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" !rowspan=2| Scoring systems !!colspan=2| Premenopausal !!colspan=2| Postmenopausal |- ! Sensitivity !! Specificity !! Sensitivity !! Specificity |- ! RMI I | 44% || 95% || 79% || 90% |- ! LR2 | 85% || 91% || 94% || 70% |- ! SR | 93% || 83% || 93% || 76% |}
Ovarian cysts may be classified according to whether they are a variant of the normal [[menstrual cycle]], referred to as a functional or follicular cyst.<ref name=HELM2013>{{Cite journal|last=Helm|first=William|title=Ovarian Cysts|url=http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/255865-overview|accessdate=30 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907142104/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/255865-overview|archivedate=7 September 2013|df=|date=2018-04-27}}</ref>
Ovarian cysts are considered large when they are over 5 cm and giant when they are over 15 cm. In children, ovarian cysts reaching above the level of the umbilicus are considered giant.
===Functional=== Functional cysts form as a normal part of the menstrual cycle. There are several types of cysts: *[[Follicular cyst of ovary|Follicular cyst]], the most common type of ovarian cyst. In menstruating women, a follicle containing the [[ovum]], an unfertilized egg, will rupture during ovulation. If this does not occur, a follicular cyst of more than 2.5 cm diameter may result.<ref name=HELM2013 /> *[[Corpus luteum cyst]]s appear after ovulation. The [[corpus luteum]] is the remnant of the follicle after the ovum has moved to the [[fallopian tube]]s. This normally degrades within 5 to 9 days. A corpus luteum that is more than 3 cm is defined as cystic.<ref name=HELM2013 /> *[[Theca lutein cyst]]s occur within the [[Ovarian follicle#Thecal|thecal layer]] of cells surrounding developing oocytes. Under the influence of excessive [[human chorionic gonadotropin|hCG]], thecal cells may proliferate and become cystic. This is usually on both ovaries.<ref name=HELM2013 />
===Non-functional=== [[File:Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst.jpg|thumb|[[Transvaginal ultrasonography]] of a hemorrhagic ovarian cyst, probably originating from a [[corpus luteum cyst]]. The coagulating blood gives the content a cobweb-like appearance.]] [[File:Endometrioma.jpg|thumb|[[Transvaginal ultrasonography]] showing a 67 x 40 mm [[endometrioma]], with a somewhat grainy content.]] Non-functional cysts may include the following: * An ovary with many cysts, which may be found in normal women, or within the setting of [[polycystic ovary syndrome]] * Cysts caused by [[endometriosis]], known as [[chocolate cyst of ovary|chocolate cysts]] * Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst * [[Dermoid cyst]] * [[Ovarian serous cystadenoma]] * Ovarian [[mucinous cystadenoma]] * [[Paraovarian cyst]] * Cystic adenofibroma * Borderline tumoral cysts
===Associated medical conditions=== In juvenile [[hypothyroidism]] multicystic ovaries are present in about 75% of cases, while large ovarian cysts and elevated ovarian tumor marks are one of the symptoms of the [[Van Wyk and Grumbach syndrome]].<ref name=Durbin_2011>{{cite journal |vauthors=Durbin KL, Diaz-Montes T, Loveless MB | title = Van wyk and grumbach syndrome: An unusual case and review of the literature | journal = Journal of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology | volume = 24 | issue = 4 | pages = e93–6 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21600802 | doi = 10.1016/j.jpag.2010.08.003 }}</ref>
The CA-125 marker in children and adolescents can be frequently elevated even in absence of malignancy and conservative management should be considered.
[[Polycystic ovarian syndrome]] involves the development of multiple small cysts in both ovaries due to an elevated ratio of [[leutenizing hormone]] to [[follicle stimulating hormone]], typically more than 25 cysts in each ovary, or an ovarian volume of greater than 10 mL.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dewailly|first1=D|last2=Lujan|first2=ME|last3=Carmina|first3=E|last4=Cedars|first4=MI|last5=Laven|first5=J|last6=Norman|first6=RJ|last7=Escobar-Morreale|first7=HF|title=Definition and significance of polycystic ovarian morphology: a task force report from the Androgen Excess and Polycystic Ovary Syndrome Society.|journal=Human Reproduction Update|date=May 2014|volume=20|issue=3|pages=334–52|pmid=24345633|doi=10.1093/humupd/dmt061}}</ref>
Larger bilateral cysts can develop as a result of [[Assisted reproductive technology|fertility treatment]] due to elevated levels of [[human chorionic gonadotropin|HCG]], as can be seen with the use of [[clomifene]] for follicular induction, in extreme cases resulting in a condition known as [[ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Altinkaya|first1=SO|last2=Talas|first2=BB|last3=Gungor|first3=T|last4=Gulerman|first4=C|title=Treatment of clomiphene citrate-related ovarian cysts in a prospective randomized study. A single center experience.|journal=The Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology Research|date=October 2009|volume=35|issue=5|pages=940–5|pmid=20149045|doi=10.1111/j.1447-0756.2009.01041.x}}</ref> Certain malignancies can mimic the effects of clomifene on the ovaries, also due to [[Human chorionic gonadotropin#Uses|increased HCG]], in particular [[gestational trophoblastic disease]]. Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs more often with invasive moles and choriocarcinoma than complete molar pregnancies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Suzuki|first1=H|last2=Matsubara|first2=S|last3=Uchida|first3=S|last4=Ohkuchi|first4=A|title=Ovary hyperstimulation syndrome accompanying molar pregnancy: case report and review of the literature.|journal=Archives of Gynecology and Obstetrics|date=October 2014|volume=290|issue=4|pages=803–6|pmid=24966119|doi=10.1007/s00404-014-3319-0}}</ref>
===Risk of cancer=== A widely recognised method of estimating the risk of malignant ovarian cancer based on initial workup is the ''risk of malignancy index'' (RMI).<ref name="NICE2011">[http://publications.nice.org.uk/ovarian-cancer-cg122/appendix-d-risk-of-malignancy-index-rmi-i NICE clinical guidelines Issued: April 2011. Guideline CG122. Ovarian cancer: The recognition and initial management of ovarian cancer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922075958/http://publications.nice.org.uk/ovarian-cancer-cg122/appendix-d-risk-of-malignancy-index-rmi-i |date=2013-09-22 }}, Appendix D: Risk of malignancy index (RMI I).</ref> It is recommended that women with an RMI score over 200 should be referred to a centre with experience in ovarian cancer surgery.<ref name="sign2003">{{cite book|last1=Network|first1=Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines|title=Epithelial ovarian cancer : a national clinical guideline.|date=2003|publisher=SIGN|location=Edinburgh|isbn=978-1899893935|chapter-url=http://www.sign.ac.uk/guidelines/fulltext/75/section3.html|chapter=EPITHELIAL OVARIAN CANCER SECTION 3: DIAGNOSIS|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922074417/http://www.sign.ac.uk/guidelines/fulltext/75/section3.html|archivedate=2013-09-22|df=}}</ref>
The RMI is calculated as follows:<ref name="sign2003"/> :RMI = ultrasound score x menopausal score x CA-125 level in U/ml.
There are two methods to determine the ultrasound score and menopausal score, with the resultant RMI being called RMI 1 and RMI 2, respectively, depending on what method is used:<ref name="sign2003"/>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:32%;"| Feature ! style="width:34%;"| RMI 1 ! style="width:34%;"| RMI 2 |- | Ultrasound abnormalities:
* Multilocular cyst * Solid areas * Bilateral lesions * [[Ascites]] * Intra-abdominal metastases | {{plainlist | * 0 {{=}} no abnormality * 1 {{=}} one abnormality * 3 {{=}} two or more abnormalities }} | {{plainlist | * 0 {{=}} none * 1 {{=}} one abnormality * 4 {{=}} two or more abnormalities }} |- | Menopausal score | {{plainlist | * 1 {{=}} premenopausal * 3 {{=}} postmenopausal }} | {{plainlist | * 1 {{=}} premenopausal * 4 {{=}} postmenopausal }} |- | CA-125 | Quantity in U/ml | Quantity in U/ml |}
An RMI 2 of over 200 has been estimated to have a [[sensitivity and specificity|sensitivity]] of 74 to 80%, a [[sensitivity and specificity|specificity]] of 89 to 92% and a [[positive predictive value]] of around 80% of ovarian cancer.<ref name="sign2003"/> RMI 2 is regarded as more sensitive than RMI 1.<ref name="sign2003"/>
==Treatment== Cysts associated with [[hypothyroidism]] or other [[Endocrine system|endocrine]] problems are managed by treating the underlying condition.
About 95% of ovarian cysts are [[benign]], not cancerous.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Ovarian-cyst/Pages/Symptoms.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090512043024/http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Ovarian-cyst/Pages/Symptoms.aspx |archivedate=2009-05-12 |df= |date=2017-10-23 }}</ref>
Functional cysts and hemorrhagic ovarian cysts usually resolve spontaneously.<ref name="V.T.2014">{{cite book|author=V.T.|title=Understanding Ovarian Cyst|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6CmRAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT25|date=14 May 2014|publisher=V.T.|pages=25–|id=GGKEY:JTX84XQARW9|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316121625/http://books.google.com/books?id=6CmRAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT25|archivedate=16 March 2015|df=}}</ref> However, the bigger an ovarian cyst is, the less likely it is to disappear on its own.<ref name="Bluth2000">{{cite book|author=Edward I. Bluth|title=Ultrasound: A Practical Approach to Clinical Problems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qms5Ei7XEC8C&pg=PA190|year=2000|publisher=Thieme|isbn=978-0-86577-861-0|pages=190|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312140433/https://books.google.com/books?id=Qms5Ei7XEC8C&pg=PA190|archivedate=2017-03-12|df=}}</ref> Treatment may be required if cysts persist over several months, grow, or cause increasing pain.<ref name="Orshan2008">{{cite book|author=Susan A. Orshan|title=Maternity, Newborn, and Women's Health Nursing: Comprehensive Care Across the Lifespan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=91dAzl2J_LgC&pg=PA161|year=2008|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-0-7817-4254-2|pages=161|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312140214/https://books.google.com/books?id=91dAzl2J_LgC&pg=PA161|archivedate=2017-03-12|df=}}</ref>
Cysts that persist beyond two or three [[menstrual cycle]]s, or occur in post-[[menopausal]] women, may indicate more serious disease and should be investigated through [[ultrasonography]] and [[laparoscopy]], especially in cases where family members have had [[ovarian cancer]]. Such cysts may require surgical [[biopsy]]. Additionally, a [[blood test]] may be taken before surgery to check for elevated [[CA-125]], a [[tumour marker]], which is often found in increased levels in ovarian cancer, although it can also be elevated by other conditions resulting in a large number of false positives.<ref>{{MedlinePlusEncyclopedia|007217|CA-125}}</ref>
===Pain=== Pain associated with ovarian cysts may be treated in several ways: *[[Pain reliever]]s such as [[acetaminophen]], [[nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs]],<ref name=Women2014/> or [[opioids]]. *While [[hormonal birth control]] prevents the development of new cysts in those who frequently get them,<ref name=Women2014/> it is not useful for the treatment of current cysts.<ref name=Grime2014/>
===Surgery=== Although most cases of ovarian cysts involve monitoring, some cases require surgery.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Diseases of the Human Body|last=Tamparo|first=Carol|last2=Lewis|first2=Marcia|publisher=Library of Congress|year=2011|isbn=978-0-8036-2505-1|location=Philadelphia, PA|pages=475}}</ref> This may involve removing the cyst, or [[oopherectomy|one or both ovaries]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fcs.tamu.edu/health/health_education_rural_outreach/Health_Hints/2003/jan-feb/gynecologic_health.php |title=HealthHints: Gynecologic Health (January/February, 2003) |format= |work=Texas AgriLife Extension Service: HealthHints |accessdate= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070217195247/http://fcs.tamu.edu/health/Health_Education_Rural_Outreach/Health_Hints/2003/jan-feb/gynecologic_health.php |archivedate=2007-02-17 |df= }}</ref> Technique is typically [[laparoscopic]], unless the cyst is particularly large, or if pre-operative imaging suggests malignancy or complex anatomy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Surgit|first1=O|last2=Inegol Gumus|first2=I|title=Single-port Laparoscopic Total Hysterectomy and Bilateral Salpingo-oopherectomy Combined with Burch Colposuspension.|journal=Acta Chirurgica Belgica|date=2014|volume=114|issue=4|pages=0|pmid=26021429}}</ref> In certain situations, the cyst is entirely [[Resection (surgery)|removed]], while with cysts with low recurrence risk, younger patients, or which are in anatomically eloquent areas of the pelvis, they can be drained.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cho|first1=MJ|last2=Kim|first2=DY|last3=Kim|first3=SC|title=Ovarian Cyst Aspiration in the Neonate: Minimally Invasive Surgery.|journal=Journal of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology|date=October 2015|volume=28|issue=5|pages=348–53|pmid=26148782|doi=10.1016/j.jpag.2014.10.003}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nohuz|first1=E|title=[How I do...the aspiration of an adnexal cyst without iterative needle punctures neither irrigation-aspiration device during a laparoscopy].|journal=Gynecologie, Obstetrique & Fertilite|date=11 December 2015|pmid=26701109|doi=10.1016/j.gyobfe.2015.11.001|volume=44|issue=1|pages=63–6}}</ref> Features that may indicate the need for surgery include:<ref>[https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/001504.htm Ovarian cysts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002121813/http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/001504.htm |date=2013-10-02 }} from [[MedlinePlus]]. Update Date: 2/26/2012. Updated by: Linda J. Vorvick and Susan Storck. Also reviewed by David Zieve</ref> *Persistent complex ovarian cysts *Persistent cysts that are causing symptoms *Complex ovarian cysts larger than 5 cm *Simple ovarian cysts larger 10 cm or larger than 5 cm in postmenopausal patients *Women who are menopausal or [[perimenopausal]]
==Frequency== Most women of reproductive age develop small cysts each month, and large cysts that cause problems occur in about 8% of women before [[menopause]].<ref name=Women2014/> Ovarian cysts are present in about 16% of women after menopause and if present are more likely to be cancer.<ref name=Women2014/><ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Benign ovarian cysts are common in asymptomatic premenarchal girls and found in approximately 68% of ovaries of girls 2–12 years old and in 84% of ovaries of girls 0–2 years old. Most of them are smaller than 9 mm while about 10-20% are larger [[macrocyst]]s. While the smaller cysts mostly disappear within 6 months the larger ones appear to be more persistent.<ref name=Cohen_1992>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cohen HL, Eisenberg P, Mandel F, Haller JO | title = Ovarian cysts are common in premenarchal girls: A sonographic study of 101 children 2-12 years old | journal = AJR. American Journal of Roentgenology | volume = 159 | issue = 1 | pages = 89–91 | year = 1992 | pmid = 1609728 | doi = 10.2214/ajr.159.1.1609728 }}</ref><ref name=Qublan_2010>{{cite journal |vauthors=Qublan HS, Abdel-hadi J | title = Simple ovarian cysts: Frequency and outcome in girls aged 2-9 years | journal = Clinical and Experimental Obstetrics & Gynecology | volume = 27 | issue = 1 | pages = 51–3 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10758801 }}</ref>

'''PGY''', short for '''postgraduate year''', refers to a [[North America]]n numerical scheme denoting the progress of postgraduate dental, medicine, podiatry or pharmacy residents in their [[residency (medicine)|residency]] programs. It is used to stratify responsibility in most training programs and to determine [[salary]]. The grade of the resident is denoted with a numeral after the PGY designation, such as PGY-3 for a third-year resident.
The length of residency depends mostly on the field a graduate chooses to take. Medical specialties such as [[family medicine]] and [[internal medicine]] often requires three years, whereas [[surgery]] usually requires a minimum of five, and neurological surgery is the longest at seven years. Subspecialization (vascular or orthopedic spine surgery as a branch of surgery, for example) in any field will add time to postgraduate training.
For more information on specific medical residency programs, see the [[American Medical Association| American Medical Association's]] [[FREIDA Online| Fellowship and Residency Electronic Interactive Database]].
Dental residencies for [[general Practice Residency|general practice]], known as GPRs, are generally one year, with a possibility of a second year at some facilities. Dental specialties, such as [[orthodontics]], require 2–4 years, while [[oral and maxillofacial surgery]] requires 4–6 years. Some specialty programs require that applicants have completed at least a one-year GPR residency, while other programs require applicants to have some private practice experience as a general dentist. Regardless of requirements, completing a GPR residency will make an applicant more competitive for any specialty program.
[[Medical physics]] residencies range between two and four years, with at least two years fulfilling the necessary clinical experience. Completion of a CAMPEP-accredited residency allows one to sit for board examinations administered through the [[American Board of Radiology]]. PGY-3, and/or if also available -4, generally consist of scholarly research years, akin to a postdoctoral research position. Residencies options are either radiation oncology physics or medical imaging.
Pharmacy residencies are usually one year, but a PGY-2 can be completed, often as an option, for pharmacy specialties such as critical care, cardiology, oncology, etc.
In some teaching institutions, trainees are required to indicate level of training on all signatures (John Doe, M.D., PGY-1 or R-1; or John Doe, D.O., PGY-1 or R-1).
Residencies are also offered for those in the [[physician assistant]] profession in a variety of specialties such as surgery and emergency medicine.
Internships and residencies are also offered for those who have completed graduate education in psychology, known as interns and post-doc fellows.
==External links== * [https://www.ama-assn.org/life-career/search-freida-online-ama-residency-fellowship-database FREIDA, the AMA's online residency database]
[[Category:Medical education in the United States]]
* [https://web.archive.org/web/20080921052833/http://www.ashp.org/Import/ACCREDITATION/ResidencyDirectory.aspx ASHP's online pharmacy residency database]

{{For|other people with this name|Peter Knight (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Peter James Knight | image_size = | image_caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1954|1|1}} | birth_place = {{NSWcity|Bathurst}}, [[New South Wales]] | death_date = | death_place = | alias = | charge = | motive = [[Christian fundamentalism|Christian fundamental]] beliefs | conviction = [[Murder]] | conviction_penalty = [[Life imprisonment]];
with a minimum [[parole|non-parole]] period of 23 years | conviction_status = In custody | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Peter James Knight''' (born 1 January 1954) is an [[Australia]]n [[Anti-abortion movements|anti-abortion]] activist who shot dead a security guard in a [[Melbourne]] [[abortion]] clinic. Following his arrest and a criminal trial, Knight is serving a [[Life imprisonment|life sentence]] with a minimum [[parole|non-parole]] period of 23 years. ==Early years and background== Knight was one of six children born into a [[Roman Catholicism in Australia|Roman Catholic]] family in {{NSWcity|Bathurst}}, [[New South Wales]]. He led a hermit's life in the years leading up to the incident{{cite AustLII|litigants=R v Knight|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/vic/VSC/2002/498.html|link= |court=VSC|num=498|year=2002|pinpoint=|parallelcite=|date=19 November 2002|courtname=auto|juris=|ref=}} in a bush camp in the Killanbutta State Forest near {{NSWcity|Molong}}, 'off the grid' without a telephone or electricity. He did, however, frequently attend anti-abortion rallies in [[Sydney]] and Melbourne. Knight was also opposed to smoking, smokers, tobacco companies and the taking of oaths. ==Murder and legal proceedings== On 16 July 2001 he walked into the East Melbourne Fertility Clinic, a private abortion provider, carrying a rifle and other weapons{{cite news|title=Abortion clinic guard killer jailed for life|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/stories/s730342.htm|work=[[The World Today (Australian radio program)|The World Today]]|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|format=transcript|date=19 November 2002|access-date=5 May 2018}} including {{convert|16|l}} of [[kerosene]], three lighters, torches, 30 gags, and a handwritten note that read "We regret to advise that as a result of a fatal accident involving some members of staff, we have been forced to cancel all appointments today". Knight later stated that he intended to massacre everyone in the clinic, and attack all Melbourne abortion clinics. He developed home made mouth gags and door jambs to restrain all patients and staff inside a clinic while he doused them with the kerosene.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/deluded-prolife-crusader-peter-james-knight-kills-guard-but-wanted-more-dead-after-he-brought-his-gun-and-hatred-to-an-abortion-clinic-in-melbourne/news-story/c5a432d3036f9d745640a3c02810dab9|title=Deluded pro-life crusader Peter James Knight kills guard, but wanted more dead after he brought his gun and hatred to an abortion clinic in Melbourne|author=Anderson, Paul|work=[[Herald Sun]]|date=11 March 2014|access-date=5 May 2018}} He shot 44-year-old Stephen Gordon Rogers, a security guard, in the chest, killing him. Staff and clients overpowered him soon after. He intended to massacre the 15 staff and 26 patients at the clinic by burning them alive. For many weeks after his arrest Knight refused to answer questions or cooperate with police investigations. Due to his hermitic life, [[Victorian Police]] were unable to confirm his identity until three months after his arrest, even though his photographs were published in major newspapers. According to psychiatrist Don Sendipathy, Knight interpreted the [[Bible]] in his own unique way and believed in his own brand of [[Christianity]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/11/19/1037697662403.html|title='Remorseless' recluse gets life|author1=Berry, Jamie|author2=Munro, Ian|work=[[The Age]]|date=19 November 2002|access-date=23 November 2012}} After choosing to not obtain legal representation, Knight was found guilty by a [[trial by jury|jury]]{{cite news|url=https://www.centralwesterndaily.com.au/story/752703/peter-knight-guilty-of-abortion-clinic-murder/|title=Peter Knight guilty of abortion clinic murder|work=[[Central Western Daily]]|date=23 April 2002|access-date=5 May 2018|author=}} and, on 19 November 2002, he was sentenced to life in prison, with a minimum non-parole period of 23 years. Knight will be aged in his 70s before being eligible for parole. On 14 May 2003 Knight lodged an [[appeal]] against his conviction; however his appeal was dismissed as it was not lodged within fourteen days of his sentence, as required under the law.{{cite AustLII|litigants=R v Knight|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/vic/VSCA/2004/48.html|link=|court=VSCA|num=48|year=2004|pinpoint=|parallelcite=|date=25 March 2004|courtname=auto|juris=|ref=}}{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/security-guard-killer-peter-james-knight-loses-appeal-bid-over-death-of-steven-rogers/news-story/f7fc8c79d996e0ef1eae7888b59bd79f|title=Security guard killer Peter James Knight loses appeal bid over death of Steven Rogers|work=news.com.au|author=Iaria, Melissa|agency=[[Australian Associated Press]]|date=20 May 2011|access-date=5 May 2018}} He is currently serving time in [[HM Prison Barwon]], near [[Geelong]]. This incident is the only killing by an anti-abortion activist in Australia's history.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/apr/24/news/mn-39628|title=Man Convicted in Deadly Abortion Clinic Shooting|author=|date=24 April 2002|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2012}} ==See also== *[[Anti-abortion violence]] *[[Abortion in Australia]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{cite AustLII|litigants=R v Knight|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/vic/VSCA/2004/48.html|link=|court=VSCA|num=48|year=2004|pinpoint=|parallelcite=|date=25 March 2004|courtname=auto|juris=|ref=}} *{{cite AustLII|litigants=R v Knight|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/vic/VSC/2002/498.html|link=|court=VSC|num=498|year=2002|pinpoint=|parallelcite=|date=19 November 2002|courtname=auto|juris=|ref=}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Knight, Peter}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Australian activists]] [[Category:Australian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Australian prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment]] [[Category:Australian hermits]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from New South Wales]] [[Category:Anti-abortion violence]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment by Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Abortion in Australia]] [[Category:Australian anti-abortion activists]] {{AUS-crime-bio-stub}} {{abortion-stub}}

'''Project SCUM''' was a plan proposed in 1995 by [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company]] (RJR) to sell cigarettes to members of the "[[alternative lifestyle]]" areas of San Francisco, in particular the large number of [[gay]] people in the [[The Castro|Castro]] and homeless people in the [[Tenderloin, San Francisco, California|Tenderloin]]. The acronym "SCUM" stood for "subculture urban marketing." Perhaps recognizing the offensive nature of its label, the marketing plan was later renamed '''Project Sourdough'''.Anne Landman, [https://web.archive.org/web/20030525040449/http://tobaccodocuments.org/landman/518021121.html Project Scum], original Project Scum document images with analysis, Tobacco Documents Online An anti-smoking campaign called [[TheTruth.com|Truth]] targeted R. J. Reynolds for Project SCUM, arguing that it not only showed the usual exploitative tobacco marketing techniques but added to them an explicit contempt or even hatred for the people it was trying to market its products to. ''[[SF Weekly]]'' reported:
"This is a hate crime, plain and simple," says Kathleen DeBold, who directs the Washington, D.C.-based [[Mautner Project]] for Lesbians With Cancer. "What else do you call it when a group thinks of gays and lesbians as 'scum,' and then targets us with something that kills?"
San Francisco Supervisor Chris Daly, who represents the Tenderloin District, is equally upset. "It's racist, it's classist, it's oppressive. And it is really disheartening to hear. But I can't say that I am surprised. Low-income communities and people of color have always been derided and taken advantage of. Obviously, the tobacco companies feel like they can make money off other people's misery."[http://www.sfweekly.com/2001-05-02/news/smoking-gun/ San Francisco - News - Smoking Gun]
Project SCUM documents came to light after a court order forced R. J. Reynolds to hand them over during the State of California's litigation against tobacco companies. R. J. Reynolds's marketing in the 1990s of its Camel and Winston cigarette brands drew the attention of attorneys representing California cities and counties. Project SCUM highlighted how tobacco companies in the 1990s were targeting young adults to be lifetime smokers.[http://www.lieffcabraser.com/Case-Center/Multi-State-Tobacco-Suits-and-Master-Settlement.shtml Multi-State Tobacco Litigation - www.lieffcabraser.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108150133/http://www.lieffcabraser.com/Case-Center/Multi-State-Tobacco-Suits-and-Master-Settlement.shtml |date=2016-01-08 }} Revelations about Project SCUM were among the mountains of evidence ensuring that anti-tobacco litigation would continue. In 1998, a resolution of the litigation came about in the [[Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement|Master Settlement Agreement]] between more than 40 state attorneys general and the tobacco industry. ==See also== * [[TheTruth.com|"Truth" ad campaign]] * [[Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement|Master Settlement Agreement]] * [[American Legacy Foundation]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite web |url=http://tobaccodocuments.org/landman/518021121.html |title=Tobacco company's internal document detailing Project SCUM |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140727225312/http://tobaccodocuments.org/landman/518021121.html |archive-date=27 July 2014 |series=Anne Landman's Collection}} * [http://www.americanlegacy.org/2114.aspx American Legacy Foundation's statement on Project SCUM] * [http://www.glma.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=Feature.showFeature&CategoryID=5&FeatureID=112 Gay and Lesbian Medical Association's statement on Project SCUM] [[Category:Class discrimination]] [[Category:Types of marketing]] [[Category:Tobacco advertising]] [[Category:1990s in LGBT history]] [[Category:LGBT history in San Francisco]] [[Category:LGBT and the economy]] [[Category:Smoking in the United States]] [[Category:Homelessness in the United States]] [[Category:R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company]] [[Category:Intersectional LGBT topics]] [[Category:Intersectional social class topics]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2012}} {{cleanup|reason=needs better grammar, phrasing and sourcing.|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox medical intervention | Name =Pulpotomy | ICD10 = <!-- 0C?W-X) --> | ICD9 = | MeshID =D011672

A '''pulpotomy''' is the removal of a portion of the pulp, including the diseased aspect, with the intent of maintaining the vitality of the remaining pulpal tissue by means of a therapeutic dressing.<ref>{{cite web | title = pulpotomy | url = http://www.ada.org/glossaryforprofessionals.aspx#p | work = American Dental Association }}</ref> A healthy tooth has a space inside it called the "pulp space" which is filled with soft tissues - nerves, blood vessels, and pink connective tissue. When a carious process develops in a tooth, the bacteria associated with it can cause pulpal inflammation, which is often what causes toothache.
[[File:Tooth-01.png|thumb|Diagram of general tooth anatomy.]]
Damage to the pulp of permanent teeth usually requires a root canal treatment or [[endodontic therapy]]. The pulp of primary or deciduous teeth, which only have to survive until an adult teeth come in, and because they have a better blood supply, can sometimes be saved.
==Indications==
===Primary teeth=== Primary/deciduous (baby) teeth in children have relatively large pulp spaces. Caries do not have to develop significantly before they reach the pulp chamber.
[[File:Tooth-02.png|thumb|Visual of tooth decay.]]
When the soft tissue in the pulp chamber is ''infected'' (has bacteria in it) or ''affected'' (is inflamed), it can be removed by a dentist or dental therapist under local anaesthetic. If the soft tissue in the canals is still healthy enough, a special medicated filling can be put into the chamber in an attempt to keep the remaining pulp (in the canals) alive. The process of removing the pulp from the chamber is the actual "pulpotomy", though the word is often used for the entire process including placement of the medication. There are many medicaments that can be used to fill the pulp chamber including zinc-oxide eugenol as well as mineral trioxide aggregate.
There are two types of pulpotomy techniques depending the extent of caries in a tooth and the symptoms it presents. A vital pulpotomy or a non-vital pulpotomy can be carried out. However, recent research shows that non-vital pulpotomies are rarely indicated due to their low success rates and it is therefore sometimes better to extract the tooth.
[[File:Tooth-03.png|thumb|Diagram of pulpotomy.]]
Afterwards the tooth is restored with a regular filling, either composite or amalgam, or a stainless steel crown. Due to the process of a pulpotomy causing the tooth to become slightly brittle, a stainless steel crown is normally indicated as the preferred choice of definitive restoration.
A pulpotomy can be done to both permanent and primary teeth.
== Types ==
=== Partial Pulpotomy for Carious Exposures === In some cases, radicular pulp (pulp within the root of a tooth) may remain healthy despite carious exposure of the pulp chamber. In cases where root formation is incomplete (as during adolescent years), a partial pulpotomy may keep radicular pulp vital long enough to allow the roots to develop fully.<ref name="pmid27931467">{{cite journal | vauthors = | title = Guideline on Pulp Therapy for Primary and Immature Permanent Teeth | journal = Pediatric Dentistry | volume = 38 | issue = 6 | pages = 280–288 | date = October 2016 | pmid = 27931467 | doi = | url = http://www.aapd.org/media/policies_guidelines/g_pulp.pdf }}</ref>
=== Partial Pulpotomy for Traumatic Exposures === A partial pulpotomy for traumatic exposures is also called a Cvek Pulpotomy. When a baby tooth or young permanent tooth is traumatised - say, hitting your teeth on the handlebars of a bike - it can be broken in such a way that the pulp is exposed. Again, a partial pulpotomy may help it to finish developing and be saved.
=== Adult Pulpotomy === Adult pulpotomies are not as popular with dentists today as they were 100 years ago. Historically, traditional endodontia has been reported to be a more reliable treatment than pulpotomy techniques, based on the rate of saved teeth and the longevity of their preservation.However, new research is changing this view. The pulpotomy, as a therapeutic dental treatment, has a long history. It has been used for thousands of years.<ref>{{cite journal | publisher = Glidewell Laboratories | title = Is It Time to Do Routine Adult Pulpotomies? | url = http://glidewelldental.com/education/chairside-dental-magazine/volume-7-issue-1/clinical-techniques-is-it-time-to-do-routine-adult-pulpotomies/ | journal = Chairside Magazine | volume = 7 | issue = 1 }}</ref>
== Medicaments == In primary teeth medicaments such as formocresol, [[mineral trioxide aggregate]], zinc oxide eugenol and [[calcium hydroxide]] can be used in pulpotomy. Formocresol use has been questioned due to toxicity concerns.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Godhi B, Sood PB, Sharma A | title = Effects of mineral trioxide aggregate and formocresol on vital pulp after pulpotomy of primary molars: An in vivo study | journal = Contemporary Clinical Dentistry | volume = 2 | issue = 4 | pages = 296–301 | date = October 2011 | pmid = 22346156 | pmc = 3276856 | doi = 10.4103/0976-237X.91792 }}</ref>
[[Ferric sulphate]], [[sodium hypochlorite]]<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Shabzendedar M, Mazhari F, Alami M, Talebi M | title = Sodium hypochlorite vs formocresol as pulpotomy medicaments in primary molars: 1-year follow-up | journal = Pediatric Dentistry | volume = 35 | issue = 4 | pages = 329–32 | year = 2013 | pmid = 23930631 | url = http://openurl.ingenta.com/content/nlm?genre=article&issn=0164-1263&volume=35&issue=4&spage=329&aulast=Shabzendedar }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Al-Mutairi MA, Bawazir OA | title = Sodium hypochlorite versus Formocresol in primary molars pulpotomies: a randomized clinical trial | journal = European Journal of Paediatric Dentistry | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 33–6 | date = March 2013 | pmid = 23597217 }}</ref> or a local anaesthetic solution containing a vasoconstrictor agent can be used to arrest any bleeding from the pulp prior to the placement of medicament.
Calcium enriched mixtures have been used in permanent molar teeth with irreversible pulpitis showing positive outcomes.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Yazdani S, Jadidfard MP, Tahani B, Kazemian A, Dianat O, Alim Marvasti L | title = Health Technology Assessment of CEM Pulpotomy in Permanent Molars with Irreversible Pulpitis | journal = Iranian Endodontic Journal | volume = 9 | issue = 1 | pages = 23–9 | date = 2014 | pmid = 24396372 | pmc = 3881298 }}</ref>
==Alternative pulpotomy techniques==
=== Electro-surgery pulpotomy === Also known as non-chemical devitalization. Its mechanism of action is the [[cauterization]] of the pulp tissue. It carburizes heat-denaturated pulp and bacterial contamination.
=== Laser pulpotomy === This technique overcomes [[Histology|histological]] effects of electro-surgery. It creates a superficial zone of coagulation or [[necrosis]] that remains compatible with the underlying tissue and isolates the pulp from vigorous effects of the sub-base.
== Objectives == # Maintenance of radicular portion vitality. # Post-op clinical and [[radiographic]] evaluation should show no complications such as pain, swelling, sinus presence [[internal resorption]] or abnormal canal calcification. Additionally, the formation of a radiolucency [[wikt:subjacent|subjacent]] to the furcation in primary teeth can indicate failure. # Neither breakdown of the supporting tissue, nor [[Physical trauma|trauma]] to [[succedaneous tooth|succedaneous teeth]] should be detected.

[[File:Sizergh Castle.jpg|thumb|Sizergh Castle, [[pele tower]] and Tudor house]] '''Sizergh Castle and Garden''' is a [[stately home]] and [[garden]] at [[Helsington]] in the [[England|English]] county of [[Cumbria]], about {{convert|4|mi|km}} south of [[Kendal]]. The [[castle]], a grade I [[listed building]],<ref name="EH">{{National Heritage List for England |num=1318962 |desc=Sizergh Castle |access-date=10 July 2015}}</ref> is in the care of the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] along with its garden and estate. It is the home of the Hornyold-Strickland family.
In 2016 the Sizergh estate was included in the newly extended [[Lake District National Park]].<ref name="BBC">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-34614556 | title=Yorkshire Dales and Lake District national parks to be extended | date=October 2015 | accessdate=6 August 2016}}</ref>
== Details == [[File:Sizergh Castle against a blue sky, July 2016.jpg|thumb|The tower at Sizergh Castle, as viewed from the South]] The earliest part of the building is a tower of fourteenth or fifteenth century date.<ref name="EH" />
=== Woodwork === There are [[oak]]-panelled interiors, including the Inlaid Chamber, where the panelling is inlaid with floral and geometric patterns in pale poplar and dark [[Bog oak|bog-oak]]. The contents of the Inlaid Chamber were sold to the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] (V&A) in the 1890s and it was displayed as a reconstructed period room. The return of the panelling to its original location at Sizergh was advocated by among others [[Mark Girouard]]. The panelling returned in 1999 under a long-term loan.<ref name="VandA">{{cite web | url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/l/loans-and-exhibitions/ | title=Inlaid Room at Sizergh Castle | publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum | accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref> In 2017 it was reported that transfer of ownership to the National Trust had been made formal.<ref name="Guardian">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/jan/02/va-returns-tudor-bedroom-to-original-sizergh-castle-setting |title=V&A returns Tudor bedroom... |last=Kennedy |year=2017 |website=www.theguardian.com}}</ref>
The [[bargeboard]]s probably date from the seventeenth century.
=== Paintings === The Castle contains a variety of paintings, including the following:
* a collection of portraits of the [[Jacobite succession|Catholic Royal Stuart family]] reflects the Strickland family's links to the Jacobite court in exile at [[Saint-Germain-en-Laye]]. There are portraits by [[Alexis Simon Belle]], [[painter in ordinary]] to [[James II of England|James VII & II]] and the [[Old Pretender]], of [[Mary of Modena|Queen Mary of Modena]] and her daughter [[Louisa Maria Teresa Stuart|Princess Louisa Maria]].<ref>Corp, Edward, ''Belle, Alexis-Simon (1674–1734)'' in [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]. Oxford University Press, September 2004 (subscription or UK public library membership required for online access)</ref> * Strickland family portraits, including works by local artist [[George Romney (painter)|George Romney]],<ref>[http://www.nationaltrustcollections.org.uk/object/998426 Walter Strickland (1729 - 1761)]. National Trust Collections</ref> a portrait of Mrs Anne Strickland (the artist's mother) by [[Harriet Strickland]] (1816–1903),<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/anne-cholmeley-17961829-mrs-jarrard-edward-strickland Anne Cholmeley (1796–1829), Mrs Jarrard Edward Strickland]</ref> and a portrait of Lady Edeline Sackville.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/lady-edeline-sackville-18701918-lady-strickland-132135 Lady Edeline Sackville (1870–1918), Lady Strickland]. Your Paintings</ref>
=== Portraits gallery ===
<gallery mode=packed heights="220px"> Image: Mary Matthews (1823-1890), Madame de La Chère (05).jpg|Mary Matthews (1823-1890), Mrs Julien-Francois-Bertrand de La Chère. Image: Alice de La Chere.jpg|Marie Louise Geneviève Alice de La Chère (1856-1943), wife of Alfred Joseph Gandolfi-Hornyold (1850-1922). Image: Lord Thomas Strickland Standish (1763-1813).jpg|Lord Thomas Strickland Standish (1763-1813). Image: Henriette Rose Peronne de Sercey (05).jpg|Henriette Rose Peronne de Sercey (1770-1849) by [[François Gérard]]. Image: Thomas Strickland Standish of Sizergh (1792-1835).jpg|Thomas Strickland Standish of Sizergh (1792-1835). Image: Gasparine Ursule Ida de Finguerlin de Bischingen (05).jpg|Ursule Ida de Finguerlin de Bischingen (1805-1846), Mrs Thomas Strickland Standish of Sizergh. </gallery>
==History== The [[Deincourt family]] owned this land from the 1170s. On the marriage of Elizabeth Deincourt to Sir William de Stirkeland in 1239, the estate passed into the hands of what became the [[Strickland (surname)|Strickland]] family, who owned it until it was gifted to the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] in 1950 by [[Gerald Strickland, 1st Baron Strickland]]'s grandson Lt. Cdr. Thomas Hornyold-Strickland, 7th Count della Catena.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet Henry Hornyold-Strickland, Sizergh|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/article-1355807867628/|archive-url=https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20140205180528/http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/article-1355807867628/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-02-05|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]}}</ref>
[[Catherine Parr]], the [[Wives of Henry VIII|sixth wife]] of [[Henry VIII]] and a relative of the Stricklands, is thought to have lived here after her first husband died in 1533. Catherine's second husband, [[John Neville, 3rd Baron Latymer|Lord Latymer]], was kin to the [[dowager]] Lady Strickland.<ref>Susan E. James. ''Catherine Parr: Henry VIII's Last Love''. The History Press, 2008, 2009. pg 56.</ref><ref>[[Linda Porter (historian)|Linda Porter]], ''Katherine the Queen''. Macmillan, 2010. pg 58.</ref>
It was extended in [[Elizabethan era|Elizabethan]] times. Sir [[Thomas Strickland (cavalier)|Thomas Strickland]] went into exile with James II.
Around 1770, the great hall was again expanded in the [[Georgian era|Georgian]] style.
==Media interest== The Castle was featured in the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] documentary ''Inside the National Trust''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Video: 'Inside the National Trust': preview|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelvideo/10372939/Inside-the-National-Trust-preview.html|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=12 October 2013}}</ref>
==Garden== [[File:Sizergh Castle garden.jpg|thumb|Sizergh Castle and part of the garden]] The garden has a lake and a kitchen garden as well as an award-winning [[rock garden]]. The rock garden, which was constructed in the 1920s, is the largest [[limestone]] rock garden belonging to the National Trust. It includes part of the [[NCCPG National Plant Collection|National Collection]] of hardy [[fern]]s.
==Estate== In 1336 a grant from [[Edward III of England|Edward III]] allowed Sir Walter Strickland to enclose the land around Sizergh as his exclusive park.
The estate covers {{convert|647|ha|acre}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/home/item273909/ |title=Sizergh - Visitor information |publisher=National Trust |date= |accessdate=2012-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111084944/http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/home/item273909/ |archivedate=2012-11-11 |df= }}</ref>
===Biodiversity===
There are various types of habitat on the estate. For example, in 2014 it was reported that 35 [[Hectare|ha]] of wetland habitat was being created in the [[Lyth Valley]] on the western edge of the estate. The project received funding from [[Natural England]] as part of a [[Environmental stewardship (England)|higher level stewardship scheme]]. It is hoped to attract [[Eurasian bittern|bittern]] and other wildlife.<ref name="WG">{{cite web | url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/news/farm_and_country/11541212.Park_End_Moss_aims_to_bring_wildlife_flooding_in/ | title=Park End Moss aims to bring wildlife flooding in | work=[[Westmorland Gazette]] | accessdate=21 November 2014 | author=Dickinson, Katie}}</ref>
Sizergh has received support from the Morecambe Bay [[Nature Improvement Area]] which received three years of government grant funding (2012–15). Projects continue under the auspices of the Morecambe Bay Partnership, a registered charity.<ref name="LNP"></ref>
====Birds==== The Sizergh estate is a good place to see birds. For example, [[hawfinch]]es are attracted to the area because of its [[hornbeam]] trees, and these birds sometimes come close to the main car park.<ref>[http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/sizergh/wildlife/ Our elusive hawfinch]</ref><ref name="LNP">{{cite web | url=http://www.morecambebaynature.org.uk/hawfinch-recovery-project | title=Hawfinch recovery project | publisher=Morecambe Bay Local Nature Partnership | accessdate=7 April 2017}}</ref>
====Butterflies==== [[Argynnis|Fritillary butterflies]] live on the estate.<ref>[http://www.countryfile.com/tips-techniques/best-places-photograph-wildlife-uk The Best Places to Photograph Wildlife in the UK]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|gardening|Cumbria}} * [[Grade I listed buildings in Cumbria]] * [[Listed buildings in Helsington]] * [[Castles in England]] * [[List of historic houses in England]] * [[Strickland (surname)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Sizergh Castle}} *[https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/sizergh Sizergh Castle & Garden information at the National Trust] *[http://www.gardenvisit.com/g/siz.htm Sizergh Castle garden] *[http://artuk.org/visit/venues/national-trust-sizergh-castle-5834 Paintings at Sizergh], Art UK *[http://www.english-lakes.com/sizergh_castle.html Illustrated guide to Sizergh Castle] *[http://www.thecumbriadirectory.com/Tourist_Attractions/Gardens_and_Parks/garden_view.php?garden=sizergh_castle The Cumbria Directory - Sizergh Castle Garden]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} [[File:No smoking UK full.svg|thumb|A no smoking sign asserting that a smoker would be breaking the law]] A '''smoking ban in England''', making it illegal to [[tobacco smoking|smoke]] in all enclosed work places in [[England]], came into force on 1 July 2007 as a consequence of the [[Health Act 2006]]. Similar bans had already been introduced by the rest of the [[United Kingdom]]: in [[Scotland]] on 26 March 2006, [[Wales]] on 2 April 2007 and [[Northern Ireland]] on 30 April 2007.
==Before the smoking ban== [[File:Smoke-by-a-window-in-a-pub.jpg|thumb|upright|Before the ban, smoking was commonplace in pubs]] Before the ban many businesses voluntarily introduced bans on smoking mainly as a result of public feedback. The pub chain [[Wetherspoons]] was the first major chain to introduce a complete ban on indoor smoking, doing so in May 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wetherspoon pubs ban smoking|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4201053.stm|accessdate=19 March 2015|agency=BBC News|publisher=BBC Online|date=24 January 2005}}</ref>
[[Tobacco advertising#United Kingdom|Tobacco advertising]] had been banned in England gradually starting with a ban on [[Television Advertising]] of cigarettes in 1965 to a complete ban on all Tobacco Advertising in 2005.
==Passage of the law== On 16 November 2004 a Public Health [[white paper]] proposed a smoking ban in almost all public places in [[England and Wales]]. Smoking restrictions would be phased in, with a ban on smoking in [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] and government buildings by 2006, in enclosed public places by 2007, and pubs, bars and restaurants (except pubs not serving food) by the end of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4014597.stm |title=Smoking ban proposed for England |publisher=BBC News |date=16 November 2004 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref>
On 26 October 2005, after external challenge and debates within the Cabinet, the government announced that it would continue with its plans. All workplaces, including restaurants and pubs selling food, would have to comply by summer 2007<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4375478.stm |title=Smoke ban bill details released |publisher=BBC News |date=27 October 2005 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> However, there was widespread criticism from all sides of the argument on this, with a number of MPs threatening to try to overturn the bill. Many representatives of the licensed trade told the Government that only a total ban would work, and over 90 MPs signed a motion demanding this, with over 100 signing a petition for a free vote on the issue. It was reported on 24 November that Chief Medical Officer [[Liam Donaldson]] nearly quit over the partial ban, but decided to stay to champion a total ban.<ref name=DonaldsonQuit>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4466176.stm |title=Chief medic considered quitting |publisher=BBC News |date=24 November 2005 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> On the same day, the government released the results of the public consultation, after [[Cancer Research UK]] demanded them under the [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information Act]], which revealed that nearly 9 out of 10 respondents wanted a total ban.<ref name=DonaldsonQuit/>
On 11 January 2006, the government further announced that it would give MPs a [[conscience vote|free vote]] on an amendment to the Health Bill, submitted by the Health [[Select Committee (Westminster System)|select committee]], to instigate a comprehensive smoke-free workplace regulations. [[Secretary of State for Health|Health Secretary]] [[Patricia Hewitt]] voted in favour of the amendment and, in so doing, voted against her own Department's then publicly stated policy (i.e. the proposed partial regulations). All other parties had offered free votes on the issue which was debated on 14 February, with three options: the present compromise, a total ban, or an exemption for members' clubs only.
On 14 February 2006, the House of Commons first voted on the amendment to the original compromise plan, to extend the ban to all enclosed public places except private members' clubs. The amendment was carried with a large majority. MPs then voted on a further amendment to ban smoking in all enclosed public places including private members' clubs. Again this amendment gained significant support and was carried with a large majority. This therefore replaced the earlier successful amendment which would have allowed smoking only in private members' clubs. The legislation was passed by the House of Lords, allowing a total smoking ban in enclosed public places to come into force in England.
Political opposition did not entirely disappear at this point, the [[House of Lords]] Economic Affairs Committee accused the Government of overreacting to the threat posed by [[passive smoking]] and said that the smoking ban was symptomatic of MPs' failure to understand risk<ref>https://www.webcitation.org/5tkNlefMT?url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/health/article672477.ece</ref> on 7 June 2006.
The ban came into force on 1 July 2007, as announced on 30 November 2006 by former [[Secretary of State for Health]] [[Patricia Hewitt]], who called it "a huge step forward for public health".<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==Following the passing of the law== [[File:Outside Bushwackers - geograph.org.uk - 843721.jpg|thumb|Many pubs provide smoking areas outdoors, where smoking remains generally permitted.]] [[File:Smoking shelter, Encon, Deighton Close, Wetherby (25th October 2015).JPG|thumb|right|A smoking shelter outside an office building in England. Since 2007 such shelters have become commonplace at workplaces.]] On 30 June 2010, the recently formed Coalition Government announced that it would not be reviewing the ban.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10478753 |title=BBC News - 'No plans' for smoking ban review |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1 July 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> An attempt in October 2010 by Conservative MP David Nuttall to amend the law to exempt private members' clubs and pubs from the smoking ban was defeated in the House of Commons on its first reading.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23887598-smoking-ban-exemptions-bid-defeated.do |title=Smoking ban exemptions bid defeated | News |publisher=Thisislondon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=25 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225143157/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23887598-smoking-ban-exemptions-bid-defeated.do |archivedate=25 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Exemptions from the law==
While the ban affects almost all indoor workplaces,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/si/si2006/20063368.htm |title=The Smoke-free (Premises and Enforcement) Regulations 2006 |publisher=Opsi.gov.uk |date=16 July 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> some exemptions were provided:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/si/si2007/20070765.htm |title=The Smoke-free (Exemptions and Vehicles) Regulations 2007 |publisher=Opsi.gov.uk |date=16 July 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> * designated hotel rooms * designated rooms in [[nursing home]]s * designated rooms in [[prison]]s * designated rooms in offshore [[Oil platform|oil rig]]s * designated rooms in mental health units ''(until 1 July 2008)'' * specialist tobacconists in relation to sampling cigars and/or pipe tobacco.
An exemption was also theoretically possible within the [[Palace of Westminster]],<ref>{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Parliamentary Privilege First Report |work= |publisher=The Stationery Office |date=4 September 2007 |url=http://www.parliament.the-stationery-office.co.uk/pa/jt199899/jtselect/jtpriv/43/4309.htm |doi= |accessdate=4 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930032749/http://www.parliament.the-stationery-office.co.uk/pa/jt199899/jtselect/jtpriv/43/4309.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> as for other Royal Palaces, although members of the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] and the [[House of Lords]] agreed to observe the spirit of the ban and restrict any smoking within the grounds of Parliament to four designated outside areas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6273830.stm |title=MPs 'smoking in Commons toilets' |publisher=BBC News |date=5 July 2007 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref>
Smoking is permitted in a private residence, although not in areas used as a shared work-space. In flats with communal entrances or shared corridors, these must be smoke-free.
University [[halls of residence]] presented some dilemmas in practice as regards defining what is public and private. Several universities have imposed a blanket ban on smoking including halls of residence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/services/safety/health_and_safety/policy/2/b/13/1 |title=Part 3B Section 13.1 |publisher=.warwick.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref>
==Public transport== As part of the implementation of the smoking ban, [[Transport for London]] announced that smoking would be no longer permitted on taxis, private hire vehicles and all [[London Buses]] premises, including all [[bus shelter|bus stop shelters]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Smoking ban: impact on London's transport network|date=6 June 2007|url=https://tfl.gov.uk/info-for/media/press-releases/2007/june/smoking-ban-impact-on-londons-transport-network|website=tfl.gov.uk |publisher=[[Transport for London]] |access-date=31 July 2015}}</ref>
The [[Association of Train Operating Companies]] and [[Network Rail]] introduced an extended ban on smoking covering all railway property including all [[National Rail]] station platforms whether enclosed or not.<ref>{{cite web|title=Smoke Free Law and Vehicles|url=http://www.smokefreeengland.co.uk/faq/vehicles/|website=Smoke Free England|publisher=Smoke Free England|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> The ban has since been extended to cover the use of [[Electronic cigarette]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Saul|first1=Heather|title=Rail companies ban e-cigarettes from trains and stations|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/rail-companies-ban-ecigarettes-from-trains-and-stations-8757883.html|accessdate=12 March 2015|publisher=Independent|date=12 August 2015}}</ref> Smoking on board trains was banned in 2005 when both [[Great North Eastern Railway|GNER]] and [[Caledonian Sleeper|First Caledonian Sleeper]] withdrew smoking accommodation from their services.<ref>{{cite news|title=End of the line for train smoking|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/4192862.stm|accessdate=14 March 2015|agency=BBC News|publisher=BBC News (London)|date=29 August 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=First ScotRail withdraws smoking on Caledonian Sleeper service ahead of £1million refurbishment|url=http://www.scotrail.co.uk/content/first-scotrail-withdraws-smoking-caledonian-sleeper-service-ahead-%C3%82%C2%A31million-refurbishment|accessdate=14 March 2015|agency=First Group|publisher=First Scotrail|date=28 August 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150315130116/http://www.scotrail.co.uk/content/first-scotrail-withdraws-smoking-caledonian-sleeper-service-ahead-%C3%82%C2%A31million-refurbishment|archivedate=15 March 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The [[Tyne and Wear Metro]] was the first public transport system to ban in its entirety which has been enforced since the system first opened in 1980.<ref>{{cite web|title=How Metro was built|url=http://www.nexus.org.uk/history/how-metro-was-built|website=Tyne and Wear Metro|publisher=Nexus|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref>
==Policing of the ban==
The ban is enforced by Environmental Health Officers in England, who issue warnings and offer advice before resorting to punitive measures and have had to issue a low frequency of fines since the law came into force. However, there were some objectors who generated higher-profile legal cases, for instance {{anchor|Hugh_Howitt}}Hugh Howitt, also known as Hamish Howitt, the landlord of the Happy Scots Bar in Blackpool who was the first landlord to be prosecuted for permitting smoking in a smoke-free place under his control. On 2 August 2007, Howitt appeared before Blackpool Magistrates' Court and pleaded not guilty to 12 counts of failing to stop people smoking in his pub. On 2 December 2008, Howitt effectively had his premises licence revoked, after an appeal by Blackpool Council was upheld; he was not allowed to appeal, and Howitt had to close the Delboys Bar following the decision.<ref>{{cite news | first = James | last = Wilmore | title = Blackpool smoke ban rebel loses licence | url = http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/Legal/Licensing-law/Blackpool-smoke-ban-rebel-loses-licence | publisher = [[The Publican]] | date = 2 December 2008 | accessdate = 5 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Paul | last = Fielding | title = Bar shuts as smoking rebel loses court fight | url = http://www.blackpoolgazette.co.uk/blackpoolnews/Bar-shuts-as-smoking-rebel.4754860.jp | publisher = [[Blackpool Gazette]] | date = 5 December 2008 | accessdate = 5 December 2008}}</ref>
There have been some incidents of violence perpetrated by people refusing to obey the ban, in one of which a former heavyweight boxer, [[James Oyebola]], was shot in the head after he asked a customer at a nightclub to stop smoking<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/6912900.stm |title=Boxer shot over club smoking row |publisher=BBC News |date=24 July 2007 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> and later died of his injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/6919403.stm |title=Boxer shot in smoking row dies |publisher=BBC News |date=27 July 2007 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> However, the view of enforcement authorities is that the smoke-free workplace regulations are simple to understand, popular, and as a result largely 'self-policing'. For a short while, bars in the UK that offered [[Mu‘assel|shisha]] (the smoking of flavoured [[tobacco]] through a pipe) were still allowed to provide their services inside the establishment, however the ban covered this area in late 2007 leading to a rapid decline in [[shisha bar]]s.
A legal blunder by [[Stoke-on-Trent]] City Council meant that, while the smoking ban still applied in the city, the council were unable to issue fines to people caught flouting the law until 16 July 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=Council error stubs out smoke ban|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/staffordshire/6290462.stm|accessdate=14 March 2015|agency=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=11 July 2007}}</ref> The blunder caused the city to briefly be dubbed Smoke-on-Trent.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Edwards|first1=Kathryn|title=Smoke-on-Trent reignites debate|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/staffordshire/6293016.stm|accessdate=14 March 2015|agency=BBC Stoke|publisher=BBC|date=11 July 2007}}</ref>
==Reaction to the ban==
A group calling themselves "Freedom To Choose", launched a campaign for a [[judicial review]] of the smoke-free workplace regulations<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedom2choose.info/ |title=Freedom To Choose |publisher=Freedom2choose.info |date=12 October 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2010}}</ref> claiming a breach of the [[Human Rights Act 1998]], as it does not respect the right to privacy of people who wish to smoke in public.<ref>{{cite web|author=Swindon Advertiser|date=19 June 2007|url=http://www.swindonadvertiser.co.uk/search/display.var.1482703.0.nonsmoking_landlord_braced_for_high_court_ban_battle.php|title= Non-smoking landlord braced for High Court ban battle|accessdate=2 July 2007}}</ref> Supporters of the regulations put forward counter-arguments positing that the rights of smokers to indulge in their habit cease as soon as it negatively affects other people in the vicinity.<ref>{{cite web|author=Chris Melville|date=1 July 2007|url=http://www.eurosong.net/smokingban|title= Smoking ban: why did we have to wait for so long?|publisher=eurosong.net|accessdate=2 July 2007}}</ref> In 2010 pub landlord Nick Hogan was jailed for an offence related to the smoking ban.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Daily Mail|date=27 February 2010 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1254126/Pub-landlord-Nick-Hogan-given-smoking-ban-jail-sentence.html|title= Pub landlord is first person in Britain to be jailed over smoking ban |accessdate=14 April 2012}}</ref> In 2012 it was reported that "Five years after the introduction of the smoking ban in England, almost seven out of 10 licensees want the legislation amended to allow for separate smoking rooms in pubs".<ref>{{cite web|author=The Publican's Morning Advertiser|date=3 July 2012 |url=http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/General-News/Smoking-ban-Majority-of-licensees-want-smoking-legislation-amended-for-pubs|title= Smoking ban: Majority of licensees want smoking legislation amended for pubs |accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref>
A 2017 YouGov survey indicated growing support for the smoking ban, up to 83% from the 2007 figure of 78%. This was attributed to more smokers supporting the legislation. <ref>{{cite web|author=Action on Smoking and Health|date= 1 July 2017 |url=http://ash.org.uk/media-and-news/press-releases-media-and-news/england-a-decade-after-the-smoking-ban-heading-for-a-smokefree-future|title= England a decade after the smoking ban – heading for a smokefree future |accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
In [[health economics]], '''Time-Trade-Off''' (TTO) is a technique used to measure the [[Quality of life (healthcare)|quality of life]] that a person or group is experiencing. An individual will be presented with a set of directions such as:
Imagine that you are told that you have 10 years left to live. In connection with this you are also told that you can choose to live these 10 years in your current health state or that you can choose to give up some life years to live for a shorter period in full health. Indicate with a cross on the line the number of years in full health that you think is of equal value to 10 years in your current health state.{{Cite journal|author=Burstrom |title=A comparison of individual and social time-trade-off values for health states in the general population |journal=Health Policy |volume=76 |year=2006 |pages=359–370 |issue=3 |doi=10.1016/j.healthpol.2005.06.011 |pmid=16214258 |last2=Johannesson |first2=M |last3=Diderichsen |first3=F|display-authors=etal}}
The answer given by the individual shows how many years in the current health state they would be willing to 'trade off', in order to regain full health. This answer can be used to calculate the individual's quality of life in that health state. For example, an individual with severe [[asthma]] could be offered 10 years in their current condition, or a shorter length of time in full health. If this individual is willing to trade off two of the ten offered years in order to regain full health, this suggests that eight years in full health has the same value as ten years with severe asthma. In this case, the individual would have valued living with severe asthma at 0.8, relative to full health (defined as 1.0). TTO scores can be influenced by socio-demographic characteristics and attitudinal variables of respondents, such as age, gender, marital status, having children, health status, education level, socio-economic status, ethnicity, and religious beliefs.{{cite journal |last1=van Nooten |first1=Floortje |last2=Busschbach |first2=Jan |last3=van Agthoven |first3=Michel |last4=van Exel |first4=Job |last5=Brouwer |first5=Werner |title=What should we know about the person behind a TTO? |journal=The European Journal of Health Economics |date=18 April 2018 |doi=10.1007/s10198-018-0975-1}} Also, they can be influenced by the effects of ill health on consumptive activities and non-health-related utility.{{cite journal |last1=Adarkwah |first1=Charles Christian |last2=Sadoghi |first2=Amirhossein |last3=Gandjour |first3=Afschin |title=Should Cost-Effectiveness Analysis Include the Cost of Consumption Activities? AN Empirical Investigation |journal=Health Economics |date=February 2016 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=249–256 |doi=10.1002/hec.3162}} Time-trade-off results are often used to calculate [[quality-adjusted life year]]s (QALYs), allowing healthcare decisionmakers to combine [[Death|mortality]] and [[morbidity]] into a single interval scale. Other tools that are used to determine quality of life are the [[visual analogue scale]] (VAS), the standard gamble method, the [[EQ-5D]], the [[Health Utilities Index]] (HUI), etc. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Health economics]] [[Category:Quality of life]]
